metadata.title: Preparation, characterization of nano ZnO-blended cellulose acetate - polyurethane membrane for photocatalytic degradation of dyes from water

sections.text:
1
Effluents from dyeing and finishing processes of textile industry contain strong colour, dissolved solids, high pH and possibly heavy metals. Conventional treatments are applied to treat dyes but the secondary pollution problem is not addressed. Consequently, one of the novel advanced oxidation processes, the heterogeneous photocatalytic oxidation process has a special interest especially when solar light is used. In this work a cellulose acetate-polyureathane (CA-PU) membrane impregnated with nano ZnO as a photocatalyst was prepared by blending technique. The structure and morphology of the prepared CA-PU membrane impregnated with ZnO were analysed by FTIR, SEM with EDAX, TG-DTA, AFM and pure water flux (PWF). The photocatalytic degradation of dyes using this CA-PU/ZnO membrane was investigated towards the removal of reactive red (RR 11) and reactive orange (RO 84) using UV-light with different parameters. The maximum degradation of dyes was achieved at 40 min with an optimum pH 7. The kinetic model of Langmuir-Hinshelwood well describes the photodegradation capacity. The photocatalytic degradation of dyes RR 11 and RO 84 exhibited pseudo-first order kinetics. ZnO impregnated CA-PU membrane inherited not only the photocatalytic ability of nano-ZnO, but also good thermal stability and mechanical property. Key words: Degradation; Blend; Dyes; Polymeric membrane; Photocatalyst.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Organic pollutants enter into the water system through domestic sewage, industrial
wastes from paper mills, tanneries, meat packing plants, slaughter houses, food processing plants, plant nutrients, detergents, biocides runoff from crop lands, decomposition of organic compounds etc. Reactive dyes are one of the most important and commonly used dyes for dyeing the textile goods. The effluents from textile industry come under organic pollutants and cause contamination of water sources around the world, which is a serious concern in the environment point of view. During the process of dyeing, approximately 10-15 % of dyes were released into
2
the environment making the effluent highly coloured and aesthetically unpleasant [1]. Conventional treatments such as biological processes, adsorption, and coagulation practices are applied to treat dyes but these are ineffective as they create secondary pollution [2]. Consequently, a promising technique based on the advanced oxidation process (AOP) has been widely used to oxidize organic dyes rapidly and non-selectively [3]. As one of the novel AOP, the heterogeneous photocatalytic oxidation using solar light, developed in the 1970’s is of special interest [4]. These processes proceed via the production of hydroxyl radicals (HO • ) and superoxide anions (O2 •- ) which are generated when a semiconductor catalyst absorbs light radiation when it is in contact with water and oxygen [5].
Recently, inorganic nanoparticles zinc oxide has been an attracting significant attention
due to its outstanding physical and chemical properties and promising catalytic activity with efficient antibacterial capabilities. With one-fourth of the cost, nano-ZnO is clearly more economical than TiO2 and Al2O3 nanoparticles [6]. Since, nano-ZnO particles can be embedded well within a solid matrix (membrane), a stable operating system that simultaneously promotes the physical and chemical characteristics of the membrane may be improved. Supplementing nano-ZnO particles into the membrane also improves its hydrophilicity and the mechanical properties of the polymer matrix [7].
Membrane technology has been widely used in a variety of sectors of industries including
water desalination, wastewater treatment, pharmaceutical, food, biological, chemical, and petrochemical process and many others. It has advantages like low energy consumption, easy operation, stable effluent quality, low maintenance cost and scale-up. Membrane separation technique is being used for the waste water treatment either by means of nanofiltration (NF) or by ultrafiltration (UF) [8,9]. Moreover, it has been coupled with other technologies such as ozonation [10]. For the past few decades, hybrid processes based on membranes (micro filtration (MF), NF, reverse osmosis (RO) and UF membranes) and photocatalytic degradation have been studied. Membrane separation process integrated with photocatalysts found to be a appropriate treatment for waste water. Indeed, membranes could play the role of support matrix for the photocatalyst and if a suitable membrane is used, it will function as a selective barrier for the species to be degraded [11,12].
Several polymers have been known for a long time to synthesis membranes, nevertheless
cellulose acetate (CA) membranes are preferred due to their superior transport characteristics,
3
excellent water affinity, low protein adsorption, suitable mechanical strength, high hydrophilicity with desalting nature, excellent film forming property, and easy availability [13]. Polyurethane (PU) is also known to exhibit unique mechanical properties, primarily as a result of two-phase morphology [14-17]. It has increased flexibility, hardness, tensile strength, temperature conditions, resistance to extreme pH and which makes PU attractive for many industrial membrane separation applications. PU is a copolymer composed of short alternating flexible soft segments (like water-soluble or highly water swellable, such as polyesters or polyethers) and linked with diamines or polyols, rigid hard segments (made of aromatic diisocyanates, which are no water soluble) [18].
In this study cellulose acetate-polyurethane (CA-PU) and zinc oxide impregnated
cellulose acetate-polyurethane (CA-PU/ZnO) membranes are synthesized. The surface morphology, thermal stability, mechanical stability properties of CA-PU and CA-PU/ZnO membranes are compared using scanning electron microscopy (SEM) with energy dispersive analysis of X-rays (EDAX), Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), atomic force microscopy (AFM), thermo gravimetric-differential thermal analysis (TG-DTA) and pure water flux (PWF) measurements. The efficiency of photodegradation of RR 11, RO 84 dyes using the membrane with improved characteristics was tested. The effect of different experimental parameters like irradiation time, pH and different initial concentration on the extent of removal of dyes by polymeric membrane was investigated. The kinetics and best fitting isotherm model for the prepared membrane was suggested.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials:
sections.text:
CA (Cellulose acetate) (BDH chemicals Ltd.) was used as membrane-forming polymer.
Zinc acetate hydrate, ammonium hydroxide, ammonium nitrate, polyurethane (PU), chloroform, acetone were purchased from Sigma Aldrich, Mumbai, India. Reactive Red 11 (RR 11) and Reactive Orange 84 (RO 84) dyes were bought from M/s Sree Chemidyes, Bangalore, India. 2.2. Preparation of ZnO nano particles
By using sol–gel method nano ZnO was prepared in this method zinc acetate (135 mg)
was used as the precursor and it was dissolved using 250 mL of distilled water. An aqueous solution of ammonium hydroxide (50 % v/v) was added to the above solution with constant stirring to attain a pH of 8.5. The reaction mixture was kept at ambient temperature until gelation
4
was formed and it was retained to complete the polymerization. The obtained mixture was filtered, washed with ammonium nitrate (0.1 M), and subsequently dried by heating slowly to 90 °C until the solvent was completely evaporated. The attained powder was calcinated at 400 °C for 5 h in muffle furnace [19]. 2.3. Fabrication of CA-PU/ZnO-mixed matrix membrane
The CA-PU/ZnO was used as casting material and it was prepared by solution dispersion
blending method. The PU (36 mg) was dissolved in chloroform and CA was dissolved in acetone and stirred. To the CA solution PU was added and further stirred at 60 °C to achieve a homogeneous solution. To the above solution ZnO nanoparticles (0.1 and 0.2 wt%, respectively) were added and stirred. The prepared CA-PU/ZnO solution was uniformly coated on a glass plate using a casting knife and then immersed in distilled water at room temperature for two days to ensure complete phase separation and to leach out water soluble components from membrane. Finally, the membrane was placed in between filter papers for drying [20]. 2.4. Experimental setup
In Fig. 1 the prepared membrane was placed inside the Buckner funnel with 50 mL of
prepared dye solution and kept under sunlight at different time intervals (10 - 60 min). The filtrate was collected using suction pump after photocatalytic reaction and samples were taken at different intervals for the analysis of dye concentration. The absorbance was measured at 555 nm and 490 nm for RR 11, RO 84 respectively and the concentration of the samples was estimated using UV-Vis spectrometer. 2.5. Membrane characterization
The surface morphology of ZnO nanoparticles, bare polymeric membrane and ZnO
blended polymeric membrane were determined by using Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM) with Energy dispersive analysis of X-rays (EDAX) (Model: TESCAN Vega3). The characteristic stretching frequencies of ZnO nanoparticles, bare polymeric membrane and ZnO blended polymeric membrane were compared by using Fourier Transform Infrared Spectrometer (FTIR) (JASCO FTIR-460 plus). Thermo Gravimetric Analyzer (TGA) (SEIKO model TG/DTA 6200) was used to measure high temperature transitions and decomposition peak values in order to investigate the thermal stability of bare polymeric membrane and ZnO blended polymeric membrane. The UV-Vis spectrophotometric studies were carried out using UV/visible spectrometer (PerkinElmer Lambda 35) for determining the rate of photocatalytic degradation of
5
dyes. The surface modifications of bare polymeric membrane and ZnO blended polymeric membrane were analyzed using Atomic Force Microscope (AFM) (model: BT 02218). The pure water flux (PWF) was determined by compaction experiment at a pressure of one bar with constant temperature in dead-end mode (Sterlitech HP4750). To apply pressure, a nitrogen cylinder coupled with a pressure regulator was connected at the top of the vessel. The volume of appropriate solution taken was 180 mL. Initially water flux was measured after pressurization for 30 sec. In order to evaluate mineralization of dyes, Total Organic Carbon (TOC) and Inorganic Carbon (IC) were analyzed with a multi N/C 3100 Analytic Jena analyzer.

sections.heading: 2.6. Photocatalytic degradation experiments
sections.text:
Experiments for the adsorption study of the dyes on the prepared membrane surface were
carried out at different initial pH values by using suspensions of 50 mL volume with a concentration of 100 mg/L of dyes. pH of the solution was adjusted in the range of 3-11 with 1 M HCl (aq) or NaOH (aq). The concentrations of dye solutions were determined by measuring the absorbance using of a UV-Vis spectrometer (PerkinElmer Lambda 35). The readings were taken at the absorbance maxima 555 nm and 490 nm for RR 11 and RO 84 respectively.
The effect of irradiation time on the photodegradation of dyes was studied at various time
intervals from 10-60 min by keeping initial concentration and catalyst dosage constant. The variations in the concentration of dye solutions were measured using UV-Vis spectrometer Effect of pH on the degradation of dyes was studied by adjusting dye solution pH from acidic to basic medium (pH 3 to 11) using pH meter (EUTECH instruments PCD650) keeping the initial concentration and catalyst dosage constant for the reaction. The impact of catalyst dosage is an important factor that can strongly influence the rate of degradation of dyes; it was studied by varying catalyst dosage from 0.02 to 0.14 g and keeping the initial concentration and irradiation time constant. To study the effect of initial concentration on the degradation of dyes, the concentrations were varied from 50 to 250 mg/L with 0.1 g of catalyst and irradiation time of 40 min was maintained.
6
A Langmuir-Hinshelwood (LH) type of relationship was used to describe the dye concentration effect on its degradation and surface sites availability for the reaction. The kinetics of degradation of dyes (RR 11, RO 84) by UV irradiation using CA-PU/ ZnO was studied using the following first order kinetics equation.
where [R.RO]0 is the initial concentration dyes, KR.RO(L/mg) is the adsorption equilibrium constant of LH. k (mg/L/min) is the rate constant of surface reaction and kobs is the pseudo-firstorder rate constant.

sections.heading: 3.1. SEM with EDAX analysis
sections.text:
Scanning electron microscopy is important for the determination of membrane surface
morphology. Fig. 2 shows the formation of ZnO nanoparticles with uniform rod-like shape. Morphologies of casted CA-PU and ZnO blended CA-PU membranes showed the formation of pores on the surface during casting as shown in Fig. 2. Generally the membranes are classified as symmetric and asymmetric membranes based on the distribution of pore size. The surface of membranes prepared in this study shows the presence of micro cavities randomly distributed on the surface which confirms that the prepared membrane is an asymmetric membrane. Fig. 2C shows that ZnO nano particles are blended with the membrane. Further the pore size of the prepared membranes was measured using imageJ software and it was found to be 0.2 µm.
EDAX spectra of the pure ZnO, CA-PU and CA-PU/ZnO are shown in Fig. 2. EDAX
spectrum of pure ZnO nanoparticles shows peaks of zinc and oxygen and no other elemental peaks could be detected which confirms the presence of zinc and oxygen only. Fig. 2E shows EDAX spectrum of CA-PU membrane in which carbon and oxygen peaks are seen. Likewise, Fig. 2F shows the presence of zinc peak along with carbon and oxygen peaks which confirms blending of ZnO with CA-PU membrane. Element mapping (Fig. 3) of the synthesized membrane and ZnO impregnated membrane showed the dispersion of ZnO nanoparticles onto the membrane.
7

sections.heading: 3.2. FTIR characterization
sections.text:
FTIR study was used to interpret the interaction between ZnO and cellulose acetate –
polyurethane membrane. In Fig. 4 (a and c), peaks around 400-500 cm -1 give information about stretching vibrations of crystalline hexagonal zinc oxide (Zn-O), similar peaks were observed for ZnO blended CA-PU membrane. Perusal of literature the characteristics bands of CA were assigned to be at 3500 cm −1 can be attributed the presence of hydroxyl group and the peaks at 1050, 1743 and 1270 cm −1 corresponding to the stretching of C-O group, ether group and C-O bond of the CH2 OH group, respectively [21] . However, this peak is observed to have slightly shifted to at 1753, 1224, 1037 cm -1 and 3451 cm -1 with high intensity in the CA-PU membrane (Fig. 4 (b)) indicating the presence of interactions between CA-PU. Moreover a broadband at 3451 cm -1 in CA-PU blend membrane indicates the intermolecular association due to the formation hydrogen bonding between urethane and macromolecular chains of cellulose acetate. These interactions took place, more specifically between the -NH group from urethane and -CO from CA [22].
When the IR spectrum of ZnO/CA-PU membrane (Fig. 4 (c)) was compared with that of
pure CA-PU, the characteristic peak of –OH group was shifted from 3451 to 3443cm -1 . Similar shifts are observed for the peak located at 1724, 1252 and 1030 cm -1 . The observed shifts in the peak may be ascribed to the formation of hydrogen bonding between ZnO and CA-PU membrane [20].

sections.heading: 3.3. Atomic Force Microscopy
sections.text:
Atomic force microscope (AFM) is a useful technique to visualize specifically the surface
roughness of the membrane at the micron/submicron level [23]. Visual assessment of the present AFM images shows that pure CA-PU membrane has a surface that is covered with “valley-like peaks or mountainous”. Moreover, the surface of the CA-PU/ZnO-mixed matrix membrane with ZnO (0.1 wt%) loading was regular with even textured, and diminished “valley”-like structure as visualized in three-dimensional (3D) image as shown in Fig. 5.
The statistical analysis of CA-PU and CA-PU/ZnO-mixed matrix membranes surface
morphology as determined by the AFM are summarized in Table 1. Average surface roughness is a parameter normally used to characterize surface roughness. From AFM results, it is concluded that modified CA-PU/ZnO membrane had a smoother surface than the pure CA-PU membrane.
8

sections.heading: 3.4. Thermal Analysis
sections.text:
Thermal properties of CA-PU and CA-PU/ZnO membranes were compared using TG-DTA.
The results presented in Fig. 6 reveal that, there is a significant variation in the thermal degradation of prepared membranes. Thermal degradation of CA-PU and CA-PU/ZnO membranes involves three steps. During the first degradation step of CA–PU and CA-PU/ZnO membranes, the temperature was varied from 50 to 400 º C. The maximal degradation of CA-PU was attained at 170 ° C with weight loss of 7.1 % but for CA-PU/ZnO the maximal degradation was attained at 280 ° C with weight loss of 80.2 %. This weight loss for the prepared CA-PU and CA-PU/ZnO membranes can be ascribed to evaporation of remained solvents and highly volatile products of membrane during thermal degradation. However, CA-PU/ZnO have weight loss of 80.2 %, this may be due to the evaporation of adhesion water [24].
The second degradation step of CA-PU and CA-PU/ZnO membranes starts at 200 ° C and
390 ° C respectively, but the weight loss in the case of CA-PU/ZnO membrane is lower (8.6 %) compared to CA-PU membrane (76.1 %). This may be due to the increased decomposition of membrane without ZnO impregnation.
The degradation temperature of the third step for CA-PU and CA-PU/ZnO membranes
was comparable. Weight loss in the case of CA-PU/ZnO is 3.05 %, in the temperature range from 445-495 ° C, while for CA-PU membrane, the temperature ranges from 410 to 550 ° C with a weight loss of 11.9 %. This loss in weight percentage accounts for the degradation of cellulose acetate chains (i.e., the pyrolysis of the polymer backbone, which is also followed by deacetylation of CA) in the prepared membranes as suggested by earlier studies [25].
From the thermal studies, it is evident that ZnO impregnation minimized thermal
degradation of polymer based membrane and improved thermal stability of CA-PU/ZnO membrane. The thermogravimetric characteristic values of CA-PU and CA-PU/ZnO membrane are shown in Table 2. 3.5. Pure water flux (PWF)
PWF tests were carried out at room temperature using a dead-end filtration system
with 7 cm 2 of membrane area. The feed solution was pressurized by a nitrogen cylinder connected to feed reservoir. To minimize the compaction effect, the pre-wetted membranes were compressed for 30 min at 2 bars and then the pressure was reduced to 1 bar. After reaching
9
steady state, the permeate water was collected and water flux was calculated with the following equation:
where J0 is pure water flux (L/m 2 .h), V is permeate volume (L), A is the membrane area (m 2 ) and (h) the permeate time. 3.5.1. Pure water flux (PWF) measurement
PWF values were measured for each membrane and the obtained results are shown in
Fig. 7. Pure CA-PU membrane has low flux value. Literature suggests water flux increases in the presence of nanoparticles [26]. In this study also ZnO blended CA-PU membrane showed a high water flux value. On addition of ZnO, the hydrophobic nature was changed to hydrophilic nature and this hydrophilicity of the membrane increases the PWF [27]. It can be seen that the water flux of CA-PU/ZnO membrane is about 93.12 higher than that of CA/PU membrane which is about 66.21.

sections.heading: 3.6. Total organic carbon analysis
sections.text:
IC and TOC were analyzed for degraded dye solution. Fig. 8 shows an increase in IC
content and decrease in TOC content. This may be due to mineralization of dye by the photocatalytic activity of ZnO under solar radiations. Similar results were reported in previous papers [28]. 3.7. Effect of irradiation time
The effect of irradiation time on the extent of photodegradation of dyes (RR 11 and RO
84) was studied under sun light, experiments were carried out at regular time intervals in the range of 10-60 min with fixed initial concentration of dyes (100 mg/L) and neutral pH using circular shaped CA-PU/ZnO membrane having a diameter of 9 cm. As shown in Fig. 9A the degradation of dyes was found to increase by increasing the irradiation time. The maximum degradation was attained at 40 min and thereafter it remained almost constant. Therefore, for further studies the irradiation time was fixed at 40 min. 3.8. Effect of pH
The solution pH has an important role on the photodegradation efficiency of dyes. The
effect of pH on the photodegradation of dyes was assessed by varying pH range from 3-11 and
10
the irradiation time was fixed at 40 min using CA-PU/ZnO membrane. It was found that the solution pH has a strong influence on the degradation.
It was observed that the degradation increased as the pH of dye solution was increased as
shown in Fig. 9B. The optimum pH for efficient degradation of RR 11 and RO 84 dyes by ZnO blended polymeric membrane was 7. Normally ZnO can react with acids to produce its corresponding salt at low pH values while at alkaline pH, it reacts with a base to form complexes and neutral pH is ideally suited for better performance. 3.9. Effect of initial concentration
The effect of initial concentration of dyes on degradation was evaluated by varying the
concentrations from 50 to 250 mg/L with the prepared membrane. Irradiation time (40 min) and pH 7 were kept constant. The effect of initial dye concentration on the degradation of dyes is illustrated in Fig. 9C.
As the initial concentration increases, the degradation of dyes decreases. This relates to
the formation of HO • radicals reacting with dye molecules. As the active sites are covered with the dye ions, generation of HO • radicals on the surface of the catalyst is reduced and also the path length of the photons entering the dye solution decreases. Similar findings were reported by Rauf et al [29]. The results clearly demonstrated that the photocatalytic degradation process was efficient at low concentration of dyes. 3.10. Kinetics of photodegradation of RR 11 and RO 84
A Langmuir-Hinshelwood type of relationship is used to describe the effect of dye
concentration on its degradation. The kinetics of photodegradation with different initial concentrations (20, 40, 60, 80 and 100 mg/L) of RR 14 and RO 84 was studied with the CAPU/ZnO membrane under sunlight and the results are given in Fig. 10. Table 3 demonstrates the relationship between different initial concentrations of RR 11, RO 84 and time.
From the figures it is evident that photo degradation of RR 11 and RO 84 dyes followed
pseudo first order kinetics shows the pseudo first-order rate constants kobs and half-life t1/2 for the photo catalytic degradation Table 3 of RR 11 and RO 84 at different initial concentrations.
The kinetic model for heterogeneous photo catalysis is explained with Langmuir-
Hinshelwood kinetic expression. According to the Eq. (2), 1/kobs holds a straight line relationship with the parameter [C]0 [30].
11
The rate constant of the adsorption equilibrium and surface reaction were calculated from
the plot of initial concentrations (CO ) and 1/kobs .The k values obtained for RR 11 and RO 84 were 19.9123, 13.2749 respectively. Kop values were 0.0066, 0.0098 L/mg respectively for RR 11 and RO 84.
The regression coefficient R values of RR 11 and RO 84 are found to be 0.9916, 0.9927
respectively which suggested that the photo degradation of RR 11, RO 84, by the ZnO blended polymeric membrane fits with the Langmuir-Hinshelwood kinetic expression well and the plots between ln [Co]/[Cf] vs. time gave straight line which also confirmed that the photodegradation process followed a pseudo-first order reaction.

sections.heading: 4. CONCULSIONS
sections.text:
The degradation efficiency of dyes RR 11and RO 84 from aqueous solution using the
prepared membrane was studied with different parameters. Cellulose acetate-polyurethane membranes were prepared and they were tested with or without the synthesized nano ZnO impregnation. ZnO blended CA-PU membrane showed better characteristics. It was found to be a promising material for the degradation of dyes from aqueous solution. The maximum degradation of dyes was achieved at 40 min and the optimum pH was observed to be 7. The kinetic model of Langmuir-Hinshelwood well describes the photodegradation capacity. The photocatalytic degradation of dyes RR 11 and RO 84 exhibited pseudo-first order kinetics. ZnO impregnated membrane inherited not only better photocatalytic ability, but also good thermal stability and water flux property.

sections.text:
The authors would like to thank the University Grants Commission, Government of India
for the financial support and also thank the authorities of GRI for the encouragement.
12
